text: my name's Brian cockin I'm the
technology officer for the Center for
Internet Security the Center for
Internet security we are a nonprofit
organization based in upstate New York
we do a couple of things one is we offer
security best practice guidelines and
recommendations and we also operate the
multi-state and election infrastructure
information analysis centers
so what primarily led us to cloud
computing was we found ourselves
ultimately one day with a big data
problem we have these sensors that are
deployed around the country that are
monitoring state and local governments
and they are monitoring all incoming and
outgoing traffic from a given
organization and they're looking for
malicious activity within that network
traffic when we first started the
program nine years ago we had a small
number of sensors around 20 or so
they're generating small amounts of data
now we're close to 400 sensors
generating very large amounts of data
and so we were at a point where we
needed to make a decision as to whether
or not we wanted to invest and
additional hardware in our in our
relatively small data center or if we
wanted to look at something like cloud
bases we found that AWS as compared to
building either something on-prem or
even some going with some of the other
providers was a more cost-effective
solution working with pro servers really
a benefit to us because we didn't have
the expertise in-house to build
something within within AWS so we had an
idea of what we wanted to build we just
didn't have any idea how to get there
and the folks in Prosser really
leapfrogged us really forward and really
quickly we are processing around 68
billion logs a minute you're storing the
data in s3 and we are currently burying
the data with Athena we've been able to
basically reduce our query time down
from days and weeks down to minutes and
seconds the other thing that we're
looking forward to doing we're just
getting started with is really
leveraging the data that's within AWS
and some of the tools like AWS sage
maker to start utilizing machine
learning and finding malicious activity
within all that do
had we gone with an on-premise solution
at the point in time when we started
this journey we would have already
outgrown it and it would have already
been money not well spent
